div.p: Experimental data on cation diffusion in silicate melts and glasses at atmospheric pressure cannot be quantitatively applied to diffusion in magmas at depth because pressure and dissolved H20 have significant effects. Diffusivities of Ca and Cs in soda-lime aluminosilieate melt are reduced by roughly an order of magnitude as pressure increases from 1 to 30 kbar at 1100°C (in the case of calcium, the pressure effect is smaller at higher temperatures). The influence of dissolved H20 is opposite to and (for some ions) far more important than that of pressure: at 700°C, Cs diffusion in granitic obsidian is enhanced by four orders of magnitude by the addition of 6 wt.% H20, and Ca diffusivity increases by 2.5 orders of magnitude. Sodium diffusion, on the other hand, is relatively immune to changes in H20 content.

The retarding effect of pressure on diffusion in deep-seated magmas is largely compensated by higher magmatic temperatures, such that overall "depth" effects on diffusion are of secondary importance -diffusion rates in mantle melts are probably well approximated by 1-atm, neaxqiquidus values. Diffusion rates in crustal magmas, however, are extremely sensitive to H20 content, so that models of rate-controlled processes in hydrous magmas may be grossly in error if 1-atm diffusivity values are used.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The potential significance of ionic diffusion as a rate-controlling factor in magmatic processes was recognized some time ago by Bowen [1,2]. Curiously, Bowen's early diffusion measurements (interdiffusion of diopside and plagioclase melts) were not widely applied to models of igneous processes, perhaps because their general validity was unknown and because instruments were not available to measure diffusion gradients in natural samples. In the past 10-I 2 years, renewed and widespread interest in ionic transport in magmas has arisen, stimulated largely by the realization that many igneous systems, ranging in scale from volcanic-rock thin sections to the Earth's mantle, do not represent complete chemical equilibrium.

The recent interest in diffusion in magmas has prompted several experimental investigations, among which are the studies by Sippel [3], Carron [4], Jambon and Carron [5] and Magaritz and Hofmann [6,7] on granitic obsidian, and by Medford [8], Hofmann and Magaritz [9] and Magaritz and Hofmann [7] on basaltic melts. The combined efforts of these workers have yielded diffusion data for alkali, alkaline earth, rare earth, and transition elements in melts or glasses that encompass the normal compositional range of magmas. The results, which are summarized by Hofmann [10], are now complete enough that estimates of diffusivities (D's) can be made for many cations at all geologically reasonable temperatures. In fact, because of the systematic dependence of diffusion rates upon cation size and charge (e.g. [6,10]), approximate diffusion rates can be assigned to some cations not yet studied experimentally.

The main limitation of the existing body of diffusion data is that the values are strictly applicable only to magmas near the surface of the Earth. 0012-821X/81/0000-0000/$ 02.50 © 1981 Elsevier Scientific Publishing Company Although allowance can usually be made for the increase in magmatic temperatures with depth, any effects of other petrologic variables, such as pressure and dissolved volatiles, are difficult to predict. The purpose of this paper is to provide a basis for extrapolation of 1 -arm diffusion data to depth in the Earth. I will consider pressure and dissolved H20 content as the main variables of interest, although other volatiles clearly may have some influence in specific cases. I will draw from the small amount of published data on the effects of pressure [ 11 ] and dissolved H20 [12,13] on Ca and Cs diffusion, respectively, but I will also present new data on diffusion of Cs at upper mantle pressures and of Na and Ca in granitic melts of varying H20 content. The emphasis will be upon experimental results, although simple theoretical considerations will be discussed where appropriate as aids to generalization.

The physical significance of the activation volume necessarily varies with diffusion mechanism: In crystalline solids where a vacancy mechanism applies, V a can be resolved into two components, Vv and Vm, which are the partial molar volume of vacant sites and the volume increase per mole of activated species, respectively [14]. In melts, where the concept of a v.acant site loses significance [11,15], it is reasonable to suppose that Va ~ Vm. In no material should the activation volume be regarded as independent of temperature [16] or of diffusing species. Naghizadeh and Rice [ 17] explained variations in activation volumes for self-diffusion in several van der Waals liquids in terms of compressibility: the more corn-pressible the fluid, the greater the decrease in diffusion rate with applied pressure.

div.head: Diffusion of calcium and cesium in molten silicate at high pressures
div.p: The only previous measurements of the effect of pressure on diffusion in materials resembling magmas are those I reported [11] for Ca diffusion in a sodiumcalcium-aluminosilicate melt (29% Na20, 5% CaO, 10% Al203, 56% SiO2). Although some geological relevance was lost by use of this composition, it was chosen in order to maximize the P-T range over which diffusion data could be obtained. Because I believe that the measured pressure effects on diffusion are at least qualitatively applicable to basic magmas (diffusion systematics in amorphous silicates appear to be generally insensitive to bulk compositional changes [10]), the same melt was used for the cesium experiments reported here. Beta-emitting radiotracers were used for both elements (4SCa and 134Cs), so that dif- fusion profiles could be directly mapped on nuclear emulsion plates. The specific experimental techniques used for the Ca experiments, along with a discussion of the sources of error in the data, are given by Watson [ 11 ]. The only differences introduced in the present experiments on Cs diffusion are that (1) all runs were made in a solid-media, pistonCylinder apparatus, and (2) the soft AgC1 pressure medium used in the Ca experiments was replaced by harder but tight-fitting boron nitride that resulted in equally good preservation of the sample geometry at run conditions.

In agreement with previous studies, the activation energy for Cs diffusion at low pressure is larger than that for Ca (see Fig. 4), but it is also apparently less sensitive to changes in pressure: From the similarity in the pressure dependencies of Dca and Dcs at low temperature (1100°C), it might be deduced that it is primarily the compressibility of the bulk diffusion medium, not the compressibility of the individual cation-oxygen bonds [ 11 ], that determines the activation volume for diffusion. However, because the activation volumes for Cs and Ca diffusion differ significantly at higher temperatures, no general conclusion regarding the interrelationship between ion or melt compressibilities and Va can be drawn at the present time. Calcium and cesium diffusion systematics are obviously dissimilar (cf. sub-parallel lines in Figs. 3 and4 with "fanning" lines of Figs. 1 and2), which may indicate that the structural role of Ca in the melt is temperature and pressure dependent, while that of Cs is not. It is possible, for example, that Ca participates in the formation of anorthite-like molecules at lower temperatures, which reduces its mobility in the melt.

From the data presented above, the following conclusions can be drawn regarding the effect of pressure on diffusion in magmas: (1) changes in pressure have only a minor effect on Dca at temperatures appropriate for melting in the mantle; (2) Ca diffusion in more silicic (and therefore generally cooler) magmas of the deep continental crust is slower by as much as an order of magnitude than 1-atm diffusivity data would indicate (see Watson [11,fig. 9];(3) the rate of Cs transport is affected by pressure in a manner similar to that observed for Ca, but is more sensitive to changes in pressure at upper mantle melting temperatures; and (4) in general, the effects of temperature and pressure on Cs and Ca diffusion are compensatory, so the diffusive transport rate is relatively constant along the liquidus of a magma in P-T space.

These conclusions can probably be generalized to include all alkali and alkaline earth elements, but their applicability to other species, especially networkforming cations such as Si 4÷ and A13÷, cannot be evaluated at the present time.

div.head: General theoretical considerations
div.p: Compared with the case of pressure effects, there is relatively little basis for predicting the influence of dissolved H20 on diffusion of cations in silicate melts.

Although the dramatic reduction in viscosity of magmas by solution of water is well documented [19], the general inapplicability of the Stokes-Einstein relation precludes calculation of concurrent changes in diffusivities [10].

Two lines of evidence suggest that high H20 concentrations should result in high diffusivities of constituent ions. First, Shaw [20] has shown that the diffusion rate of H20 itself is "2 orders of magnitude faster in granitic melt containing ~6 wt.% H20 than it is in "dry" obsidian of the same composition. Diffusion of any component that assumes a structural role similar to that of H20 (e.g. alkali oxides? [21 ]) might, therefore, be similarly enhanced by the addition of H20.

The second line of evidence for enhancement of diffusion rates by addition of H20 stems from the generally "compensated" nature of diffusion in molten silicates -that is, the linear relation between log Do and E a (constants in equation ( 9)) for diffusion of many different ions in a variety of melts [22]. Winchell [22] noted that diffusion in compositions having low melting temperatures is generally characterized by low values of Do and E a. Solution of H20 is very effective in melting point reduction of silicates, so it may, if Winchell's generalization is valid, also substantially reduce Do and Ea for diffusion of other components. Because of the specific compensation relation that applies to silicate melts (see Hofmann [10] and Winchell and Norman [23]), such a reduction in Do and Ea amounts to an increase in diffusion rate at temperatures below ~1500°C. The next section will show that this prediction is borne out by experimental data for some elements.

div.p: Experimental measurements. I recently reported experimental data on diffusion of Cs ÷ in granitic melt containing ~6 wt.% H20 [13]. The experiments were carried out on dry or pre-hydrated obsidian cylinders encapsulated in 1.8-mm-diameter Pt tubes that were sealed by welding cylindrical noble metal plugs in the recessed ends. All diffusion runs were made in coldseat vessels at the same pressure (2.1-2.2 kbar), so as to standardize any possible pressure effects. Sodium diffusion profiles were determined by the "residual activity" technique of Magaritz and Hofmann [6] ; Ca profdes were directly mapped on/~-sensitive nuclear emulsions [24], and the diffusivity values were calculated from microdensitometer scans (see Watson [111).

Because the experiments on H20-bearing melts were carried out on larger samples than the dry, highpressure runs (1B mm vs. 1 mm diameter) and were run in different apparatus, some discussion of the possible sources of error in the data seems necessary. Short of performing the same experiment many times over, there is no way to obtain an accurate measure of the uncertainty in any single result. The data presented in Figs. 567include several duplications, each of which represents a small time study. There are, for example, three determinations of Dcs in melt con-taining 6% H20 at 800°C. The points represent experiments of 2, 3, and 4 days duration, and the values agree within a factor of two, with no systematic variation with run duration. This is the largest discrepancy I have observed in replicate experiments -the two Dca points at 800°C and 6% H20 show results of runs 12 hours and 2 days long, and the agreement is within a factor of 1.3. Possibly significant sources of error include (1) imperfections in nuclear emulsions or uneven exposure and development procedures, (2) the non-negligible range of /3 particles in the quenched glasses, (3) error in estimates of H20 content, (4) deformation of the diffusion capsule and thin-source geometry. I find that densitometer scans of separate emulsions exposed to the same sample give the same diffusion coefficient to within 10%; furthermore, the correlation coefficients of the linearized diffusion profiles (in C vs. x 2, where C is proportional to tracer concentration and x = distance) are always >0.988.

The/~-particle range question was indirectly addressed in the "dry" Ca diffusion experiments (see Fig. 6). These runs yielded diffusion profiles much shorter than those obtained in the "wet" experiments, and yet the resulting diffusivities are consistent with the Ba and Sr data published by Magaritz and Hofmann [6]. If the ~ range is unimportant in short diffusion profiles ('200/am), as it appears to be, then it will be insignificant in long (1-3 mm) ones.

The water contents of the samples were estimated by weight loss at 1100°C from pieces of the hydrated glasses separated prior to the diffusion runs. The values were occasionally low for the 6% H20 hydrations, in which cases the samples were discarded. The H20 contents of several glasses were checked after diffusion runs and found to be close to (usually slightly higher than) the predicted values.

I believe that the largest source of error in the experiments is sample deformation. Despite the hydrostatic pressure conditions in the cold-seal vessels, the platinum diffusion capsules were generally slightly distorted from their initial cylindrical form; in particular, the inner surface of the Pt plug at the thin-source end sometimes acquired a slightly convex shape, thus invalidating the utilization of a strictly thin-source model. On the whole, however, the results are consistently reproducible, and a factor of two can probably be taken as the maximum uncertainty in any diffusion coefficient obtained from a single run.

Systematics of the data. The data summarized in Figs. 567show that H20 has two effects on diffusion in granitic melts at the temperatures studied: (1) the diffusion coefficients generally increase with increasing H20 content;and (2) the activation energies for diffusion generally decrease. In the case of Na, the effect is small (and conceivably within the limits of uncertainty in the data), but for Cs diffusion at 700°C, Dcs is almost 4 orders of magnitude higher for melt containing "6 wt.% H20 than for dry glass. The "hydrous" activation energy is less than half the "dry" value. For Ca, the difference in diffusion coefficient is about 21 orders of magnitude and the activation energies differ by 16%. In Fig. 8, the 700°C results are re-plotted to show the dependence of diffusion coefficients on H20 content for all three elements. It should be noted that the data for Cs are in qualitative agreement with those of Jambonet al. [12], but that the present results indicate a less pronounced positive dependence of Dcs upon H20 content. The one value reported here for diffusion of Na in dry obsidian (700°C) is a factor of wt% H20 in melt 2 lower than previously reported values [3,4,6], a discrepancy that can be attributed either to the uncertainty in the present result or to the 2.2-kbar difference in pressure (previous experiments were carried out at 1 atm). I favor the latter interpretation because sample deformation was slight in the dry experiments of the study. Although the data are too few at the present time for valid generalization, two tendencies seem apparent: (1) ions with very low diffusion rates in dry obsidian undergo the greatest enhancement of diffusivity (and reduction in activation energy) upon addition of H20; and (2) the variations in diffusion parameters attributable to solution of H20 are consistent with the general compensation law of Winchell [22] -that is, the observed decreases in Ea with increasing H20 content are accompanied by decreases in log Do. A corollary to the first observation above is that ions with high diffusivities in dry obsidian (e.g., Na*) are enhanced very little by addition of H20, perhaps suggesting that there is an upper limit to cation diffusion rates in amorphous silicates. Finally, it seems clear that enhancement of diffusion rates by dissolved H20 is not restricted to ions of any particular chemical affinity, since both an alkali element (Cs) and an alkaline earth (Ca) are much more mobil in H20-bearing melts than in dry glass.

When I first presented the data for Cs diffusion in an H20-saturated melt [13], I proposed a simple atomistic explanation for the enhanced mobility in H20-rich compositions: Because the solution of H20 amounts to widespread creation of non-bridging oxygens [25], the number of structural positions favorable for occupation by Cs ÷ is greatly increased as H2 O is added. This creation of potential sites results in a reduction of the average diffusive jump distance for Cs ÷, so the diffusivity increases. The additional data now available support this simple conceptualization in that the pre-exponential factor, Do, generally decreases with addition of H~O to the melt. In atomistic theories of diffusion, the jump distance (or, in crystals, the lattice spacing) is a primary component term in Do [14]. Thus, the general decrease in Do that characterizes the effect of H20 on diffusion in melts may reflect the hypothesized reduction in average diffusive jump distance.

Alternatively, the changes in ionic diffusion rates upon addition of H20 might be viewed simply as the difference between diffusion in a solid and diffusion in a liquid: Dry obsidian is a metastable, essentially solid substance that is characterized by well-defined sites [26], whereas the H20-bearing compositions are stable fluids that by definition lack fixed sites.

div.head: Summary of petrologic implications
div.p: In magmas at depth in the earth, the effect of pressure on ionic diffusion is always operative, whereas that of H20 is obviously dependent upon its presence and concentration. In hydrous magmas, the two effects are simultaneous and opposite. In spite of the fact that pressure and H20 content were varied essentially independently in the experiments reported here (so as to isolate their effects), it is possible to draw some general conclusions about diffusion in magmas at various levels in the crust and upper mantle:

(1) In magmas of the upper crust, the retarding effects of pressure on diffusion are probably unimportant for most ions. However, enhancement of diffusion rates by dissolved H20 may be extremely important, especially for ions whose 1-arm diffusivities are low. If the magma is dry, then 1-atm diffusion data can be applied with confidence, but such data may be entirely inappropriate if H20 is present.

(2) In magmas of the lower continental crust (especially cooler felsic compositions), the effects of both pressure and H20 content on diffusion are probably substantial. For calcium and cesium in dry magmas at "--40 km depth, a factor of ~5 reduction in diffusion rate relative to the 1-arm value is likely. However, if even 1 wt.% H20 is present, the inhibiting effects of pressure on diffusion may be more than counteracted. Existing experimental data are insufficient to allow confident prediction of diffusion rates in lower-crustal magmas, but it should be noted that quantitative relevance of 1 -arm data would be fortuitous.

(3) In magmas at upper mantle pressures, diffusion rates may be as much as an order of magnitude lower than 1-atm values at the same temperature. It should be realized; however, that the higher temperatures of magmas at great depth will at least partially compensate the pressure effect. Even the presence of H20 in mantle melts may be of relatively little consequence compared with its effects in crustal magmas. In the 700-800°C range over which the enhancing effect of H20 on diffusion has been documented, a decrease in the activation energies for diffusion is also observed, especially for the alkalies. This implies that the "dry" and "wet" diffusivities converge at high temperature (see, for example, Fig. 5). Thus, on the whole, diffusion rates in mantle magmas are probably surprisingly well represented by available 1-atm values.

From the foregoing observations, it appears likely that the conclusions of Hofmann and Magaritz [9] and Hofmann and Hart [27] concerning the time scales of trace element and isotopic mixing in a partially molten mantle are valid. However, previous conclusions regarding crustal magmatic and geochemical processes drawn on the basis of diffusion data for dry obsidian [6] are subject to revision in light of the marked enhancement of diffusion rates that accompanies solution of H20 in magmas. For example, the estimate of Magaritz and Hofmann [6] of the diffusive transport distance of Sr during a million-year-long crustal migmatization episode is probably unrealisti-cally low. Their assumed temperature of 700°C may be appropriate for incipient melting of crustal rocks if H20 is present, but it is well below the solidus under the water-free circumstances for which their Dsr value of 10 -1 t cm2/s was selected. On the basis of the Ca diffusion data presented here, the predicted value for Dsr in a melt containing 6% dissolved H20 is ~10 -a cm2/s. This 3-order-of-magnitude difference in Dsr would result in a 30-fotd (i.e., x/103) increase in the estimated diffusive transport distance for Sr. This change does not affect the conclusion of Magaritz and Hofmann that Sr isotopic equilibration cannot occur on a regional scale in 106 years, but it does increase from centimeters to meters the scale of sampling required for Rb-Sr whole rock dating of the partial melting event.
